According to the Pew Research Center survey, American perceptions of China's role in handling the COVID-19 pandemic have significantly soured. As shown in image2, the Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan is considered a great deal to blame for the global spread of the virus. In fact, around two-thirds of Americans (64%) believe that China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [8]. This sentiment is reflected in the rising unfavorable views of China, with 73% of U.S. adults now holding such views, up 26 percentage points since 2018 [11].

Moreover, as seen in image3, Republicans and those leaning towards the GOP are more critical of China. In 2020, 73% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents viewed China unfavorably, compared to 37% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [4]. This partisan divide is also evident in the desire to hold China accountable for its actions. While 50% of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for the role it played in the outbreak, even at the expense of economic relations, Republicans are significantly more likely to support this stance, with 71% agreeing compared to 37% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [6].

The evolving perceptions have also impacted broader U.S.-China relations, particularly regarding economic ties. As illustrated in image1, while more Americans still see the U.S. as the world's leading economy (52%), views of U.S. economic superiority have declined by 7 percentage points over the past four months. Additionally, those who see China as economically dominant are less likely to support getting tough on China economically, instead prioritizing building a strong relationship with China on economic issues [2]. Furthermore, the survey indicates that while Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should pursue a strong economic relationship or get tough on China, more Americans (51%) prefer a strong economic relationship, even if it means overlooking any role China played in the outbreak [3].

In summary, American perceptions of China's role in handling the COVID-19 pandemic have led to a significant increase in unfavorable views and a shift in attitudes towards China, particularly among Republicans. These evolving sentiments have also influenced broader U.S.-China relations, with a preference for maintaining economic ties over a tough stance.

![Older Americans turn even more negative toward China in recent months](image1) reveals a significant shift in negative perceptions of China, particularly among older Americans. Since 2019, the percentage of Americans aged 50 and older who have a very unfavorable view of China has nearly doubled from 23% to 42%, indicating a substantial increase in negative sentiment. This trend is consistent with the data from [8], which shows that negative views have increased by 26 points since 2018.

Moreover, [3] and [5] highlight that Americans aged 50 and older are more negative towards China compared to younger generations. Specifically, 81% of those aged 50 and older have an unfavorable view, compared to 71% of those aged 30 to 49, and 56% of those under 30. Additionally, the increase in unfavorable views among the older generation since March is 10 percentage points, further emphasizing the generational divide in perceptions.

Regarding political affiliations, [1] and [2] show that Republicans and Republican-leaning independents have consistently held more unfavorable views of China compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. Since 2012, the share of Republicans who see China as an enemy has increased by 21 percentage points, whereas the increase among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents has been 8 percentage points. This widening gap is evident in the graph showing the difference in unfavorable views between Republicans and Democrats, which has increased from +19R in 2015 to +35R in 2020.

The image [10] illustrates the overall trend of negative views of China, indicating that 73% of Americans have an unfavorable view today, a 26-point increase since 2018. This underscores the broad and sustained negative sentiment across the population, with [9] and [11] reinforcing that negative opinions have sharply increased in recent months, especially among older Americans and Republicans.

In summary, negative perceptions of China have intensified among older Americans and Republicans, while younger and Democratic-leaning individuals tend to hold more favorable views. This polarization reflects broader geopolitical tensions and differing ideological perspectives on the relationship between the United States and China.

The unfavorable views of China have notably increased over the years, particularly among older Americans and Republicans. As shown in image7, the percentage of people with a very unfavorable view of China reached a record high of 42% in 2020, nearly doubling since the spring of 2019 when only 23% held such a view. This increase is starkly illustrated in image8, where the gap between the percentages of Republicans (54%) and Democrats (35%) who hold a very unfavorable view of China has widened significantly. 

Furthermore, according to text quote [5], there has been a notable increase in negative views among Americans aged 50 and older, with 81% now holding an unfavorable opinion, compared to 71% for those aged 30 to 49, and 56% for those under 30. This trend is consistent with the data presented in image5, which shows that the unfavorable view among older Americans has increased by 10 percentage points since March.

In terms of political affiliation, the data from text quote [8] and image1 indicate that Republicans have become even more negative towards China recently, with their unfavorable view increasing by 11 percentage points in the past four months. This is in contrast to Democrats, whose unfavorable view increased by only 6 points during the same period. Text quote [10] further supports this by noting that around three-quarters (73%) of Americans have an unfavorable view of China today, marking the most negative reading in the 15 years that Pew Research Center has been measuring these views.

The demographic analysis provided in text quote [6] suggests that negative views of China are consistent across educational levels, with around seven-in-ten individuals, regardless of their level of education, expressing unfavorable opinions. Additionally, there is little difference in views between men and women.

Overall, the unfavorable views of China have evolved to become more pronounced among older Americans and Republicans, reflecting broader shifts in public sentiment and political alignment. 

![The unfavorable view among older Americans has increased by 10 percentage points since March](image5)

The views on China have significantly shifted across different age groups and political affiliations, with notable changes observed over time. According to the data from the Pew Research Center, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents hold a much more unfavorable view of China compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, with an 83% unfavorable view among Republicans versus 68% for Democrats [4]. This gap widens further when looking at the percentage of people with a very unfavorable view, where 54% of Republicans and 35% of Democrats express such sentiments [4].

Looking at age groups, the data indicates a stark contrast in opinions. Among those aged 50 and older, 81% have an unfavorable view of China, while those aged 30 to 49 hold a slightly lower but still high view with 71% [6]. Those under 30, however, have the lowest unfavorable view at 56%. The shift in opinion among the 50+ age group is particularly significant, with an increase of 10 percentage points since March [6].

The image `![Republicans and Democrats' views on China](image1)` visually represents this divide, showing that Republicans have consistently held more unfavorable views than Democrats, with the gap increasing over time. Additionally, the image `![Views of China by age group](image2)` highlights the generational divide, with older Americans being substantially more negative towards China compared to younger generations.

Moreover, the Pew Research Center found that the negative opinion of China has sharply increased in recent months. The percentage of Americans with a very unfavorable view of China has nearly doubled since the spring of 2019, reaching 42% in the latest survey [3]. This is reflected in the image `![Views of China over time](image7)`, which shows a steady rise in unfavorable views from 2005 to 2020, with a particularly sharp increase in the last four months.

The data also reveals that the negative views towards China are consistent across educational levels and genders. About 73% of Americans today have an unfavorable view of China, marking the most negative reading in the 15 years that the Pew Research Center has been measuring these views [7]. This is further supported by the image `![Overall views of China](image3)`, which shows a predominantly unfavorable opinion.

When it comes to the specific handling of the coronavirus by China, the Pew Research Center found that Republicans are much more critical, with 82% saying China has done a bad job and 61% saying it has done a very bad job [10]. In contrast, only 54% of Democrats and 30% of Democratic-leaning independents believe China has done a very bad job. The image `![Views on China's handling of the coronavirus](image6)` illustrates this divide, with Republicans showing a significantly higher unfavorable view compared to Democrats.

In conclusion, the views on China have become increasingly negative across all age groups, with a particular shift among older Americans. Politically, Republicans hold a much more unfavorable view of China compared to Democrats, and this gap has widened over time. These trends are consistent across various demographic factors and have intensified in recent months.

According to the data, negative opinions of China have significantly increased among all age groups and political affiliations in the United States, but there are notable differences across these demographics.

As shown in the graph from image6, which depicts the unfavorable opinions of China among different age groups and political affiliations, there is a substantial shift towards negativity. For instance, among those aged 50 and older, the unfavorable opinion has risen from around 68% in 2019 to 81% in 2020, marking a 13 percentage point increase. On the other hand, for those under 30, the unfavorable opinion rose from 45% to 56%, indicating a 11 percentage point increase over the same period. The trend is consistent for all age groups, showing that negative views have grown among young, middle-aged, and older Americans.

Moreover, the partisan divide in perceptions of China is stark. As seen in image2, which tracks the unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020, Republicans have consistently held more unfavorable views compared to Democrats. In 2020, 83% of Republicans had a very unfavorable view of China, whereas only 68% of Democrats did. The gap between the two parties has widened over the years, with Republicans becoming increasingly negative towards China. Specifically, since March 2020, the unfavorable views among Republicans increased by 11 percentage points, while among Democrats, they increased by 6 percentage points, leading to a 15-point difference between the parties.

The graph in image7 illustrates the changing attitudes towards China over time, with a particular focus on the policy preferences of different age groups. It shows that while there has been a general trend towards a more negative view, the desire to build a stronger relationship with China remains significant, especially among younger Americans. However, the preference for a tougher stance towards China has also increased, particularly among older Americans.

In conclusion, negative opinions of China have become more prevalent across all age groups and political affiliations in the United States, reflecting broader concerns about China's role in the global pandemic and other international issues. This shift is most pronounced among older Americans and Republicans, highlighting the complex interplay of age, politics, and perception in shaping attitudes towards China.

The perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has varied significantly across different age groups and political affiliations. According to the data, around three-quarters of Americans believe that the Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed to the global spread of the virus. Among Republicans, the belief is even stronger, with 73% saying that China's early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to 38% of Democrats who agree. This aligns with the image1, which shows the stark difference in opinions between Republicans and Democrats regarding China's responsibility for the global spread of the virus.

Furthermore, the data indicates that older Americans, specifically those aged 50 and older, are particularly critical of China's response to the pandemic. A significant portion of this groupâ€”81%â€”hold unfavorable views of China, an increase of 10 percentage points since March. This is reflected in image6, which demonstrates the higher levels of negativity towards China among older Americans.

In comparison to the general unfavorable views of China, the data from Pew Research Center shows that Republicans have consistently held more unfavorable views of China than Democrats over the past 15 years. In the most recent survey conducted in June and July 2020, 83% of Republicans had an unfavorable view of China, compared to 68% of Democrats. This is illustrated in image5, where the unfavorable view of China is higher among Republicans than among Democrats. Additionally, the data shows that older Americans are more likely to have a very unfavorable view of China, with 54% of Republicans aged 50 and older holding such a view, compared to 35% of Democrats in the same age group.

The image7 further supports this trend, showing that 83% of Republicans believe China has done a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak, compared to 68% of Democrats. This aligns with the sentiment expressed in the text quotes, where a majority of Americans, including a substantial number of Republicans, are highly critical of China's response to the pandemic.

Overall, the perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has become increasingly negative among both Republicans and older Americans, with these groups being more critical than Democrats and younger individuals. This negative sentiment is consistent with the general unfavorable views of China, which have been higher among Republicans for many years and have intensified recently, as shown in the data and visual representations provided.

![Americans are highly critical of the way China has handled the coronavirus outbreak](image1) According to the survey data, around two-thirds of Americans believe that China has not handled the coronavirus outbreak well, with a significant portion of respondents saying it has done a very bad job. ![Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus](image5) Specifically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more critical, with 82% believing China has done a bad job, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners.

The perceptions also vary across age groups. For instance, older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and over, are more critical of China's response to the pandemic. As shown in the graph, 73% of those 50 and older find fault in China's handling, which is higher than the 64% for the total population. Additionally, younger adults aged 18-29 are less critical, with only 54% saying China has done a bad job, though still a majority.

Regarding the responsibility of China in the spread of the virus, there is a notable difference in opinions between Republicans and Democrats. Republicans are particularly critical, with 73% believing that China's initial handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its global spread, compared to 38% of Democrats who share the same view. The same trend is seen in the perception of whether the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the outbreak. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to say the U.S. should hold China responsible even at the expense of worse economic relations.

In conclusion, the data indicates that both political affiliation and age play significant roles in shaping perceptions of China's handling of the coronavirus. Older Republicans and those with conservative leanings are the most critical, followed by younger Republicans and then Democrats.

In the United States, political affiliations significantly influence preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. For instance, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more inclined towards Israel as a partner, whereas Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents favor Canada and Mexico (text quote [2]). Interestingly, despite these differences, both Republicans and Democrats rank Germany similarly as a top foreign policy partner, albeit with Republicans showing a stronger preference for Israel (text quote [3]).

In Germany, political affiliations also play a role, but the differences are less pronounced compared to the U.S. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens all name France as the top or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. (text quote [7]). Furthermore, there is a notable difference in views regarding cooperation with Russia, with East Germans being almost twice as likely as Americans to prefer closer ties with Russia (text quote [10]). This aligns with the data indicating that Republicans in the U.S. are more supportive of increased cooperation with Russia compared to Democrats (text quote [11]).

![Germans want to cooperate more with the U.S.](image8)
This image illustrates the divergent views on cooperation between Americans and Germans. While 69% of Americans want to cooperate more with Germany, only half of Germans feel the same about the U.S. (text quote [8]). This suggests a gap in mutual desire for increased cooperation, which is influenced by political affiliations and regional factors.

In conclusion, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly impact preferences for foreign policy partners and desired levels of cooperation. These differences highlight the complex dynamics in transatlantic relations and the varying priorities across different political spectra.

According to the provided data, there are notable differences in preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China between Americans and Germans. Americans generally favor closer ties with China over Russia. For instance, among Americans aged 18 to 29, 58% prefer a close relationship with China rather than Germany, whereas 32% prefer Germany [7]. Conversely, Germans are about twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%) [8]. This stark contrast suggests that while Americans are more inclined towards China, Germans lean towards the U.S. for strategic partnerships.

The political landscape further influences these preferences. In the U.S., Democrats are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [4, 9]. Similarly, in Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU (the conservative party) are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those supporting the Greens and the SPD (the left-leaning parties) [9]. This indicates that political ideology plays a significant role in shaping preferences for international cooperation.

In terms of specific attitudes towards Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. Moreover, within the U.S., Republicans are more supportive of a closer relationship with Russia compared to Democrats [4]. However, in Germany, there is a notable difference in preferences between East and West. In the former East Germany, 75% prefer a close relationship with the U.S. compared to 63% in the former West [10].

The image quotes further illustrate these points. The first image [image1] shows that while both Americans and Germans have varying preferences for different countries, the trend is that Americans are more inclined towards the U.S., UK, France, and Japan, whereas Germans prefer the U.S., UK, France, and China. The second image [image2] highlights the political divide in the U.S., with Republicans being more supportive of a close relationship with Russia (63%) compared to Democrats (31%). The third image [image3] shows that in Germany, the Greens and SPD are less supportive of a close relationship with Russia (45% and 47% respectively), while CDU/CSU supporters are more inclined (57%).

In summary, Americans and Germans differ significantly in their preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China, influenced heavily by political affiliations. Americans generally favor China over Russia, while Germans lean towards the U.S. for closer ties. Political party affiliations in the U.S. and Germany further shape these preferences, with Republicans in the U.S. and CDU/CSU in Germany showing more support for Russia, contrasting with Democrats and SPD in Germany.

![Americans favor Germany over Russia (61% vs. 26%)](image2)
In the U.S., political party preferences significantly influence attitudes towards cooperation with other countries. Democrats are more inclined to want greater cooperation with Germany (75%) compared to Republicans (57%), as shown in the image2. This pattern is consistent when considering cooperation with Russia, where Democrats are more supportive of closer ties (32%) than Republicans (21%). This partisan divide can be seen in the image3, which illustrates the preference for a close relationship with Germany among different age groups in the U.S., with young adults showing a significant preference for Germany over China (58% vs. 32%).

![Germans are more supportive of closer ties with the U.S. than with Russia](image5)
In Germany, the situation is somewhat different. While the image5 indicates that conservatives in Germany are more favorable towards the U.S. (61%) compared to Russia (31%), the overall trend still shows a stronger preference for the U.S. (64%) over Russia (47%). However, when it comes to China, Germans are nearly twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. (50%) over China (24%), highlighting a strong alignment between German public opinion and their political leanings.

Democrats in the U.S. are also more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany (75%) than Republicans (57%). This is further supported by the image6, which shows that CDU/CSU supporters in Germany are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. (57%) compared to the Greens (45%) and the SPD (47%). This reflects the broader trend of right-leaning individuals in both countries being more favorable towards the U.S. compared to left-leaning individuals.

Overall, the data suggests that political party preferences play a crucial role in shaping attitudes towards cooperation with other countries, particularly Russia and China. Democrats in the U.S. and conservatives in Germany tend to favor closer ties with the U.S. and are less supportive of closer relationships with Russia and China, whereas Republicans in the U.S. and left-leaning individuals in Germany show a more mixed or even slightly negative view towards such partnerships.

In the United States, there is a notable difference in attitudes toward cooperation with Russia based on political affiliation. Democrats are significantly more inclined to favor closer ties with Germany rather than Russia, with 66% preferring a close relationship with Germany compared to just 57% of Republicans who share this view ([3]). This trend extends to the desire for increased cooperation; Republicans in the U.S. are 41% in favor, whereas Democrats are only 32% in favor ([8]).

In Germany, the political landscape also plays a role. The conservative parties, such as the CDU/CSU, are more supportive of U.S.-German cooperation compared to the Greens and the SPD, which are more aligned with the left of the political spectrum ([10], [11]). Additionally, residents in the former East Germany, where the CDU/CSU has stronger support, exhibit a greater preference for cooperation with Russia, with 75% of East Germans wanting more collaboration compared to 63% of those in the former West ([8], [9]).

![](image1) This graph illustrates the stark differences in perceptions regarding various countries and organizations between the U.S. and Germany. It highlights that while Germans generally have a more positive view of the EU (+18%) and Russia (+17%), the divide is particularly pronounced when it comes to the U.S., with Germans favoring it more than Americans by 5 percentage points. This aligns with the data showing that 52% of Germans have a favorable view of the U.S., compared to 47% of Americans.

The data from image2 further corroborates the generational divide in the U.S. regarding China, with younger Americans (18-29 years old) being more likely to view China favorably compared to older generations. However, this pattern does not directly relate to attitudes towards Russia.

To summarize, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. Democrats in the U.S. and conservatives in Germany are more open to closer ties with Russia, while their counterparts on the right in the U.S. and left in Germany are more supportive of closer relationships with Germany.

According to the Pew Research Center survey, there are significant differences in the views of Americans and Germans regarding the leading economic power. In the U.S., half of the respondents name the United States as the world's leading economic power, while about a third choose China (32%). Conversely, in Germany, roughly half name China as the leading economic power (53%), whereas only 24% name the U.S. as such. This disparity is also reflected in their views on the European Union (EU), where 14% of Germans name the EU as the leading economic power, a figure that is about twice as high as in the U.S. (7%). The image `![Views on Leading Economic Powers](image2)` illustrates these differences clearly, showing that Germany places more emphasis on China and the EU, while the U.S. sees itself as the leading economic power.

When it comes to international relationships, the survey reveals that Americans and Germans also have different perspectives. Americans are generally more positive towards the United Nations (UN) and NATO, with 66% and 58% viewing these organizations favorably, respectively. Germans, on the other hand, have a more positive view of the EU (71%), followed by the UN (64%) and NATO (62%). The image `![International Organizations](image4)` further highlights this difference, demonstrating that Germans are more inclined towards the EU, while Americans are more supportive of the UN and NATO. 

Moreover, the survey indicates that when it comes to cooperation with other countries, nearly seven-in-ten Americans (69%) want to cooperate more with Germany, compared to only half of Germans who feel the same way about the U.S. (see `![Cooperation with Germany](image1)`). This suggests that while Americans see Germany as a key partner, Germans are more ambivalent about their relationship with the U.S.

In summary, the views of Americans and Germans differ significantly regarding the leading economic powers and international relationships. Americans predominantly see themselves as the leading economic power and are more positive towards the U.S., while Germans place more importance on China and the EU. Additionally, there is a notable difference in their views on international organizations like the UN and NATO, with Germans being more supportive of the EU compared to Americans.

According to the Pew Research Center, Americans and Germans hold differing views on international organizations and economic powers. For instance, when asked which country is the world's leading economic power, Americans and Germans gave starkly different answers. Half of Americans named the U.S., with about a third (32%) choosing China, whereas roughly half of Germans named China (53%) as the leading economic power, compared with 24% who named the U.S. (Text Quote [7], Text Quote [8]).

![](image1)

In contrast, when it comes to views on international organizations, Germans tend to view them more positively than Americans. For example, about 70% of Germans favor the EU, while only about half of Americans agree. Similarly, Germans tend to view the UN and NATO more positively than Americans, although there is notable consensus on these organizations (Text Quote [10]). The image below illustrates these differences, showing that Germans have a more positive view of the EU (+18), Russia (+17), and China (+8) compared to Americans. 

![](image5)

These perceptions are influenced by several factors, including ideological differences. Conservatives and those on the right of the ideological spectrum in both countries are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU (Text Quote [11]). Additionally, the division is notably wider between Americans than it is between Germans on these issues.

![](image6)

Another factor is the geographical location within Germany. Germans living in the former East tend to view Russia more favorably (43%) and the EU less favorably (59%) compared to those in the former West (71% for the EU) (Text Quote [4]).

![](image7)

Age also plays a role. Younger Germans (18-29) and those aged 30-49 are more likely to favor China than older age groups (Text Quote [12]). 

In summary, Americans and Germans differ significantly in their views of international organizations and economic powers, with these differences being influenced by factors such as ideology, geographical location, and age. Americans tend to view the U.S. as the leading economic power and are more skeptical of international organizations like the EU and the UN, while Germans tend to have a more positive view of these organizations and are more likely to view China as the leading economic power.

According to the data, there is a significant difference in perception regarding the necessity of military force between Americans and Germans. In the U.S., a substantial majority of conservatives (90%) believe military force is necessary, whereas only 65% of liberals share this view. In contrast, in Germany, nearly 60% of those on the right see military force as necessary, while only about a third of those on the left agree. Additionally, Americans are more likely than Germans to believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain order in the world; approximately 80% of Americans hold this view, compared to only about 50% of Germans. This is illustrated in image1, where the gap between Republicans/Lean Rep and Democrats/Lean Dem is evident over the years (2017-2019).

On the topic of defense spending, the data shows that Americans are more inclined than Germans to support keeping the same level of spending. In 2019, 50% of Americans said that U.S. allies should maintain their defense spending levels, marking a shift from 45% in 2017 who believed they should increase their spending. However, in Germany, public opinion is more divided, with about 40% each supporting an increase or maintaining the current levels, as shown in image6. The percentage of Americans who see a need for European allies to increase national defense spending has decreased since 2017, while Germans are equally split between increasing or maintaining their budgets.

Regarding the age demographics' views on U.S.-Germany relations, there is a noticeable generational divide. In the U.S., 82% of people aged 18 to 29 view the relationship positively, compared to only 73% of those aged 65 and older. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people (ages 18-29) consider relations with the U.S. to be good, while only 31% of those aged 65 and older share this view. This is clearly depicted in image2, which shows the trend in positive sentiment towards U.S.-Germany relations over the years, with younger generations consistently more favorable than older ones.

In summary, Americans tend to be more supportive of military force and defense spending, particularly among conservatives, while Germans are more divided on these issues. Furthermore, younger generations in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-Germany relationship compared to older generations.

![Americans are more supportive of military force and defense spending](image1) According to the data, Americans are more inclined to support the use of military force compared to Germans. In the U.S., a significant majority of conservatives (90%) believe that military force is necessary, whereas only 65% of liberals share this view. Similarly, a higher proportion of Americans (80%) consider it sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, compared to just 50% of Germans.

In terms of defense spending, Americans are more likely to favor increased spending in Europe. As seen in the graph, the percentage of Americans who believe the U.S.'s European allies should increase their defense budgets has decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. However, this shift is less pronounced among Democrats.

On the other hand, ![Germans are divided on the importance of U.S. military bases](image2) Germans are more skeptical about the importance of U.S. military bases for their national security. While about half of Germans find these bases important, 45% disagree. Additionally, when asked if they believe their own country's defense spending should increase, maintain the same level, or decrease, the German public is split, with about 40% choosing to keep the same level and 25% opting for an increase.

The differences in opinion are further highlighted by the fact that ![Germans and Americans have opposing views on NATO's Article 5 obligations](image3). Six-in-ten Americans support the idea that their country should use military force to defend NATO allies against a potential Russian attack, while an equal number of Germans oppose this notion.

When it comes to defense spending, ![There is a notable difference in how Americans and Germans view their respective defense budgets](image5). In 2019, 35% of Americans believed that their European allies should increase their defense spending, 50% thought it should stay the same, and 41% suggested a decrease. For Germany, the public was equally divided, with 25% wanting an increase, 51% wanting to keep the same level, and 24% wanting a decrease.

To summarize, Americans are more supportive of military intervention and increased defense spending compared to their German counterparts, who are more cautious and divided on these issues. This divergence in opinion is evident across various aspects of defense policy, including the use of military force, the importance of foreign military bases, and the level of national defense spending.

In both the United States and Germany, opinions on defense spending have undergone shifts over recent years. In the U.S., there is a notable change in the perception of European allies' defense spending. In 2017, $45\%$ of Americans believed their European allies should increase their spending on national defense, but by 2019, this figure had dropped to $35\%$, while $50\%$ now believe it should stay the same (see image1). This shift is evident in the partisan divide, with Republicans being more likely to favor increased spending compared to Democrats, although both parties have seen a decline in support for increased spending since 2017 (refer to image2).

In Germany, the public is more divided on the issue. In 2017, about half of Germans were content with their country's defense spending, while around a third felt it should be increased. Since then, opinions have become more evenly split, with about four-in-ten Germans favoring either an increase or maintenance of current levels (see image8). The partisan gap is also significant, with supporters of the CDU/CSU generally favoring increases, while members of the Greens and SPD are more skeptical (refer to image10).

![Americans and Republicans support military bases more than Democrats and Germans](image4)
In the U.S., there is a strong belief in the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany for national security, with $85\%$ of Americans and $90\%$ of Republican-leaning independents viewing them as important (image4). In contrast, only $45\%$ of Germans agree, with about half seeing these bases as important for their own national security (refer to image7).

These evolving opinions reflect broader changes in attitudes towards international military commitments and defense spending. The partisan differences highlight the complexity of defense policy debates, where political affiliation significantly influences views on both domestic and international defense spending.

Overall, American and German opinions on defense spending have diverged, with Americans showing less pressure on allies to increase spending and a stronger emphasis on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany, while Germans are more divided and skeptical about such increases.

According to the data, there have been notable shifts in American and German views on national defense spending from 2017 to 2019. In the U.S., the percentage of people who believe that European allies should increase their defense spending decreased from 45% in 2017 to 35% in 2019 [7], indicating a shift towards maintaining the current levels of spending rather than increasing it.

In Germany, the public's opinion on increasing defense spending has also evolved. While in 2017, about half of the population was content with their country's defense spending and about a third felt it should be increased [3], by 2019, the views were more evenly split, with about 41% supporting an increase and 37% wanting to keep the same level of spending [4].

![Differences in views on defense spending](image4)

Moreover, partisan divides exist within both countries. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more supportive of increased defense spending compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. However, there has been a significant decline in Republican support for increased spending among their base, falling by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [12]. In Germany, similar to the U.S., there is a clear partisan gap, with supporters of the CDU/CSU (a center-right party) more likely to favor increased spending than those of the SPD (a center-left party) [1].

![Partisan differences in Germany](image11)

In terms of age differences in Germany, younger individuals tend to be less supportive of the importance of American military bases. For instance, 62% of those aged 18 to 29 consider these bases not important for German national security, whereas 61% of those 65 and older believe they are important [10].

![Age differences in Germany](image5)

The partisan differences in Germany can be further illustrated by the following graph showing the percentage of voters from different parties who support increasing Germany's defense spending. It shows a clear division, with CDU/CSU supporters more inclined to favor increased spending [11].

![Partisan support for defense spending in Germany](image11)

To summarize, both American and German views on national defense spending have shifted over the past few years, with a trend toward maintaining current levels rather than increasing them. Partisan differences play a significant role in shaping these opinions, with right-leaning groups generally more supportive of increased spending than left-leaning ones in both countries.

The political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly influence opinions on increasing defense spending. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more inclined to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals. However, there has been a notable decline in this view among Republicans, falling by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, as illustrated by the image showing the change in opinion over time (`image7`).

In Germany, the situation is different. The image `image9` shows that supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of defense spending increases, whereas supporters of the Greens express more skepticism, with only 28% wanting to raise defense spending. Members of the SPD fall in the middle, with 41% saying Germany should increase defense spending.

The partisan divide in the U.S. is evident when considering the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany to national security. According to the text quote [1], 85% of Americans believe these bases are important to the U.S.'s security interests, with nearly six-in-ten seeing them as very important. In contrast, the image `image5` indicates that only 52% of Germans agree that U.S. military bases are important for their country's national security, while 47% disagree.

Over time, opinions on increasing defense spending have shown some shifts. For instance, the image `image8` demonstrates that in 2019, 35% of Americans thought our European allies should increase their defense spending, 50% wanted to keep it the same, and 41% believed it should decrease. In Germany, the percentages were slightly different, with 25% thinking European allies should increase spending, 51% keeping it the same, and 24% wanting a decrease.

![Germans are not as convinced about the importance of U.S. military bases to their security as Americans are.](image5)
![Support for increased defense spending varies significantly between political parties in both countries.](image7)

In conclusion, political affiliations play a crucial role in shaping opinions on defense spending, with Republicans in the U.S. and supporters of the CDU/CSU in Germany more likely to favor increases, while Democrats and supporters of the Greens are more skeptical. Over time, there has been a shift in the U.S., with fewer Republicans supporting increased spending.

![Germany sees U.S. bases as not important](image8) illustrates the stark generational divide regarding the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany. Among younger Germans aged 18 to 29, 62% do not consider these bases important for their national security, whereas older Germans aged 65 and above are more supportive, with 38% viewing them as important. This discrepancy highlights how age plays a significant role in shaping perceptions of U.S. military presence.

In the U.S., political affiliations influence the perception of foreign policy partners, as shown in image4, where both Republicans and Democrats rank Germany as a top foreign policy partner. However, Republicans express greater enthusiasm for Israel, with 26% considering it a top partner, compared to just 9% of Democrats. Image7 further demonstrates this by showing that while both Republicans and Democrats view Germany as an important foreign policy partner, Republicans have a slightly higher affinity for Germany.

Regarding the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany, image6 presents data from 2017 to 2019, indicating a gradual increase in support for the bases among both Republicans and Democrats. By 2019, 59% of Republicans and 48% of Democrats believed the bases were important to U.S. security interests.

In summary, younger Germans tend to doubt the importance of U.S. military bases in their country, while older Germans and those with certain political affiliations in the U.S. are more supportive. These findings underscore the complex interplay between age and political ideology in shaping perceptions of foreign military presence and international partnerships.

In examining the views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues, there are clear distinctions between different political affiliations and educational backgrounds. The data indicates that more educated individuals are more inclined to support U.S. assistance to other nations, whereas those with lower education levels are more focused on domestic concerns.

For instance, image6 illustrates that 46% of respondents believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and not help other countries, while 38% think the U.S. should help other countries. This gap is evident across different demographics, but it's particularly stark when comparing those with higher education levels to those with a high school degree or less. Image6 shows that 56% of postgraduates and 50% of college graduates believe the U.S. should help other countries, whereas only 44% of those with a high school degree or less hold this view.

Additionally, the partisan divide is significant. As shown in image4, liberal Democrats are more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with 64% believing the U.S. has done a poor job, compared to 22% of conservative Republicans holding the same view. This ideological gap is reflected in their perspectives on international aid, as seen in image3, where 73% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, compared to 39% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents.

Moreover, the image5 provides insights into how different groups view the U.S. response to international issues. It reveals that 77% of conservative Republicans believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can, while only 39% of the total population holds this view. This stark difference is mirrored in the distribution of opinions among different age groups and educational backgrounds.

In conclusion, the views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues are deeply divided along political lines and educational backgrounds. More educated and liberal individuals are more likely to support international assistance, while conservative and less educated individuals prioritize domestic issues.

According to the data, political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly shape Americans' perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.

For instance, image5 illustrates the wide partisan gap in evaluating the U.S. response to the pandemic. It shows that while only 48% of conservatives and conservative-leaning individuals believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, 77% of liberals and liberal-leaning individuals hold a negative view, indicating a stark difference in opinion along the ideological spectrum [9].

Similarly, image2 highlights the partisan divide in views on China's handling of the pandemic. It shows that 80% of conservatives and conservative-leaning individuals believe China has not handled the crisis well, whereas only 50% of liberals and liberal-leaning individuals share this view [9]. This suggests that political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping perceptions of international events.

Moreover, image10 reveals that more educated Americans are more critical of the U.S.'s response to the pandemic. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree say the U.S. has done a poor job, compared to about 43% of those with a high school degree or less [10]. This indicates that education level influences how Americans perceive the effectiveness of the U.S. response.

Additionally, image11 provides insights into age-based differences. Older Americans, who tend to have less favorable attitudes toward China, are more critical of its performance. Specifically, 69% of those aged 65 and older say China has not handled the crisis well, compared to 59% of those under 30 [11].

In summary, political affiliation and educational background strongly influence Americans' perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the pandemic. Republicans and more educated individuals are generally more critical, reflecting a complex interplay between ideology, knowledge, and age. ![Partisan and educational influence on perceptions of US and China](image2)

According to the data, there are significant partisan differences in how Americans perceive the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. [10] highlights that there is a wide partisan gap in evaluating how the U.S. has dealt with the coronavirus, while smaller differences exist for other countries' responses. Specifically, [9] indicates that while majorities in all educational groups believe China has not handled the pandemic well, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view than Democrats. Conservative Republicans are particularly critical, with eight-in-ten holding this view.

![](image6) This graph clearly illustrates the difference in opinions between those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries and those who do not. For instance, regarding Germany, 70% of those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries believe Germany is handling the coronavirus outbreak well, compared to only 48% of those who think the U.S. can learn little or nothing from other countries. This trend is similar for South Korea, where the difference is +21%.

![](image7) This figure further emphasizes the partisan divide in assessing the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, 71% say the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, whereas only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents hold this view. This gap is even wider when comparing conservative Republicans (77%) and liberals (81%).

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the pandemic. Republicans generally have a more positive view of the U.S.'s response and a more negative view of China's management, while Democrats tend to hold the opposite views.

When considering the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus, there is a notable partisan divide. According to the data, liberal Democrats are much more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with 67% holding this view, compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans [8]. This difference is illustrated in Image5, which shows the percentage of respondents from different countries and political affiliations who believe the U.S. can learn from them.

Moreover, the trust levels in international organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO) and the European Union (EU) also exhibit strong partisan differences. For instance, 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO at least a fair amount, compared to just 27% of conservative Republicans [2]. Similarly, 79% of liberal Democrats have a positive view of the EU's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, whereas only 49% of conservative Republicans agree [10].

The trust in information from the EU and WHO is also higher among those with a college degree or higher, as seen in Image6, where 72% of college graduates and 78% of postgraduates trust information from the EU. However, the primary driver of trust appears to be political affiliation rather than education level.

In conclusion, the perception that the U.S. can learn from other countries in managing the coronavirus is significantly influenced by political affiliation, with liberal Democrats being far more optimistic about learning from other nations compared to conservative Republicans. This aligns with the higher trust levels in international organizations like the WHO and EU among liberal Democrats, as opposed to conservative Republicans.

The views about the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level.

Firstly, regarding political affiliation, there are clear partisan gaps in perceptions of the U.S.'s international influence. According to quote [1], Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened post-crisis, whereas Democrats are more likely to think it will weaken. This gap is even more pronounced within the Democratic party, where liberal supporters are more pessimistic about the U.S.'s influence (quote [1]). Similarly, there is a large divide over China's influence, with Republicans and older Americans more likely to view China negatively (quotes [2] and [6]). The data also show that when asked about the EU's influence, majorities from both parties expect it to remain unchanged (quote [3]).

Secondly, education plays a role in shaping these views. Higher education levels correlate with a perception that the U.S.'s global influence will decrease. For instance, quote [10] indicates that Americans with higher educational attainment are more likely to think the country's global influence will recede.

The images further illustrate these trends. Image1 shows the distribution of views based on education level, highlighting that those with higher education are more likely to believe the U.S.'s influence will weaken (total 41%, postgraduates 37%, etc.). Image6 demonstrates the difference in views between Republicans and Democrats on China's influence, with Republicans being more likely to believe China's influence will diminish (conservatives 27%, liberals 86%).

In summary, political affiliation and education level significantly influence views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China. Republicans and those with higher education tend to be more pessimistic about the U.S.'s and China's global influence, while Democrats and those with lower education levels are more optimistic. ![Political and Educational Influence on Views](image1)

The predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China vary significantly among different demographic and political groups after the coronavirus outbreak. For instance, Republicans are more likely to believe that the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis, whereas Democrats are more inclined to predict that American influence will weaken (see image3). This partisan divide is stark, with Republicans being about twice as likely as Democrats to expect the U.S. to gain influence, and Democrats being four times more likely to anticipate a decline in U.S. influence (quote [3]).

Regarding China, there's a notable consensus that its global influence may decline. A majority of Americans (50%) believe that China will have less influence in world affairs post-pandemic (quote [7]). This view is shared across various demographic segments, though there are some nuances. For example, higher education levels correlate with a greater belief that the U.S. will lose global influence (quote [9]), and older Americans are more likely to predict a decrease in China's global power (quote [11]).

Interestingly, the predictions for the U.S. and China diverge. While half of Americans think China will have less influence, fewer hold the same view for the U.S. or the European Union (quote [10]). This suggests a relative optimism about the U.S.'s ability to maintain its global standing despite the pandemic, contrasting with the pessimism regarding China's future influence.

The image4 provides a visual representation of these differences, showing a significant gap between Republican and Democratic views on China's influence, with Democrats being much more likely to see a decline. The image5 illustrates that among all educational levels, Democrats and those leaning Democratic are more likely to predict a decline in China's influence, reflecting the broader political divide.

In summary, the predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak are deeply influenced by political affiliation and age, with Democrats and older Americans generally more pessimistic about both countries' global influence, while Republicans tend to be more optimistic about the U.S. and somewhat less so about China.

![Many believe China has not handled the crisis well](image9) According to the data, a majority of Americans believe that China has not done a good job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak. Specifically, nearly two-thirds of Americans (66%) have an unfavorable opinion of China, with 37% saying the country has done a poor job. This perception is reflected in the image where a significant portion of respondents indicate that China has not handled the crisis well.

![China's influence will decline after the coronavirus outbreak](image11) Furthermore, when asked about China's future influence in world affairs, half of Americans believe it will decline following the pandemic. This sentiment is evident in the image showing a balanced distribution of opinions, with 20% believing China's influence will grow and another 31% thinking its global standing will remain the same.

The partisan divide is stark. For instance, conservative Republicans are particularly critical of China, with eight-in-ten holding the view that China has not handled the crisis well. In contrast, Democrats are much more likely to believe that China has done a good job: 62% of Democrats think the World Health Organization (WHO) has done an excellent or good job, whereas only 28% of Republicans agree. Similarly, when asked about the WHO's performance, a majority of Democrats (67%) and moderate and conservative Democrats (58%) give the WHO positive reviews, while only 21% of Republican conservatives do so.

These perceptions and the resulting partisan differences are illustrated in the image depicting the trust levels in the WHO, where Democrats and moderate/conservative Democrats overwhelmingly trust the organization, while Republicans express much lower levels of trust. Additionally, the image showing the U.S.'s assessment of its own performance during the pandemic highlights the stark contrast between Democratic and Republican viewpoints, with 81% of liberal Democrats believing the U.S. has done only a fair or poor job, compared to just 22% of conservative Republicans holding the same view.

In summary, Americans, especially those on the conservative end of the political spectrum, perceive China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decline in China's global influence post-pandemic. These perceptions are deeply rooted in partisan divisions, with Democrats generally viewing China more favorably and Republicans more critically.

According to the data from 2013 to 2020, there are significant partisan differences regarding the U.S. role in solving world problems and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak. The graph in `image1` shows that the percentage of Republicans believing the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges has increased from 2013 to 2020, reaching 62% in 2020, while Democrats remain largely opposed to this view, with only 26% sharing this sentiment.

Additionally, the survey indicates that most Americans think the U.S. can learn from other countries about how to limit the spread of the coronavirus. However, there are stark differences between Democrats and Republicans on this issue. As shown in `image10`, 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries, whereas only 28% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents agree.

Furthermore, the graph in `image6` illustrates the partisan divide on the U.S.'s international influence. Democrats are more likely to expect the U.S. to lose influence due to the coronavirus outbreak. Specifically, 81% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has only done a fair or poor job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, compared to 22% of conservative Republicans holding the same view. Moreover, the belief that the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the outbreak is significantly higher among liberal Democrats (56%) than among moderate and conservative Democrats (15%) and even more so among conservative Republicans (8%).

In conclusion, Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges and are less inclined to see the U.S. learning from other countries to combat the coronavirus. Conversely, Democrats are more likely to perceive the U.S. as doing poorly in handling the crisis and anticipate a decline in U.S. international influence. These trends have been consistent since 2013, as indicated by the data presented in the graphs.

![The U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about ways to slow the spread of the coronavirus](image2) According to the data, there are significant partisan differences regarding the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries. While 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. can learn a great deal, only 28% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents share this view ([11]). This indicates that Democrats are more optimistic about the potential for learning from other nations.

Additionally, partisan views differ on the U.S.'s role in global affairs. A larger proportion of liberal Democrats (64%) believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems compared to 39% of the general population ([9]). Moreover, liberal Democrats (56%) are more pessimistic about the U.S.'s future influence in world affairs post-pandemic, believing it will have less influence, whereas only 8% of conservative Republicans share this view ([3]).

![The U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems](image5) The data also highlights that there is a strong belief among Democrats, especially liberal Democrats, that the U.S. should help other countries. For instance, 64% of liberal Democrats support this idea, while only 22% of conservative Republicans agree ([3], [9]). This divide is evident in other areas as well; for example, 81% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, compared to 22% of conservative Republicans ([3]).

In summary, Democrats, particularly liberal Democrats, tend to see the U.S. as having a greater responsibility to help other countries and believe the U.S. can learn from international responses, while Republicans, especially conservative ones, are less inclined to see the U.S. in such a role and are more skeptical about the value of international cooperation.

PEW RESEARCH CENTER's findings reveal significant variations in views on the U.S. dealing with its own problems versus helping other countries, depending on political affiliation and educational level.

For instance, the data show that Democrats are more inclined to believe that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems (64% of liberal Democrats vs. 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats). This is illustrated in image6, where Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more likely to support helping other countries, with 60% saying the U.S. should help. In contrast, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to prioritize dealing with domestic issues, with 77% wanting the U.S. to handle its own problems (image7).

Moreover, the relationship between education and these views is evident. Postgraduates, who are better educated, are more likely to support the U.S. helping other countries (66%, see image1), while those with lower educational attainment are more likely to prefer the U.S. focusing on its own issues (43%, image1). The data in image2 further confirm this trend, showing that highly educated individuals (postgraduates and college graduates) are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about slowing the spread of the coronavirus (56% and 50%, respectively).

In summary, the evidence suggests that Democrats and more educated Americans are more likely to advocate for the U.S. helping other countries and learning from them, while Republicans and those with lower educational attainment tend to prioritize addressing domestic issues. This pattern is consistent across different demographic groups, as seen in the trends shown in images1 through 8.

In the current survey, conducted among members of Pew Research Center's American Trends Panel, a majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, whereas Democrats (48%) are more likely to say the U.S. does too little. This significant divide is evident when we look at the data across different age groups and educational levels, as shown in image1. The figure indicates that the percentage of Republicans who think the U.S. does too much is consistently higher compared to Democrats, regardless of age or education level.

Furthermore, the partisan gap in perceptions has widened over time. As shown in image6, in 2013, only 26% of Republicans believed the U.S. did too much, compared to 48% in 2020. This shift is even more pronounced when we consider the trend line, which demonstrates a steady increase in the percentage of Republicans who think the U.S. does too much to solve global challenges.

The ideological divide among Democrats is also noteworthy. According to image8, liberal Democrats are more likely to support the idea that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, with 64% agreeing, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats. This suggests that while there is a general trend towards Republicans believing the U.S. does too much, the internal division within the Democratic Party is more nuanced, with liberal Democrats being more supportive of international aid.

Additionally, the data reveals that more educated Americans are more critical of the U.S. role in addressing global issues. Image7 shows that 66% of postgraduates believe the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job, compared to 43% of those with a high school degree or less. However, these perceptions are most divided along party lines. Image4 illustrates that while a majority of Democrats (73%) and Democratic-leaning independents (63%) rate the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak more negatively, a similar proportion of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (71%) praise the country's handling of the outbreak. This partisan divide is further emphasized by the racial disparities in evaluations, where Black and Hispanic Americans rate the U.S. response more negatively than white, non-Hispanic Americans (see image5).

In conclusion, the data clearly shows that perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems are significantly influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans more likely to believe the U.S. does too much and Democrats more likely to believe the U.S. does too little. These perceptions have become more polarized over time, particularly among Republicans, who have increasingly viewed the U.S. as overcommitting to global challenges.

According to the data, there is a notable divide in views on U.S. global engagement and domestic issue handling between Republicans and Democrats, as well as between different levels of educational attainment.

For Republicans, a majority (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, while only 8% think it does too little, and 29% believe it does the right amount (image1). This sentiment is reflected in their preference for the U.S. to focus on its own problems rather than helping others (image9). The partisan divide is stark, with 77% of conservative Republicans believing the U.S. should deal with its own problems (image1).

On the other hand, Democrats are more likely to think the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems (48%), with 26% each saying it does the right amount or too much (image1). Liberal Democrats are even more inclined to support international assistance, with 64% believing the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems (image2). This ideological difference within the Democratic Party is also evident in other measures, such as the belief that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems (image9).

Educational attainment plays a significant role in shaping these views. Higher levels of education correlate with a greater willingness to support international assistance. For instance, 60% of postgraduates say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, compared to 44% of those with some college experience and 43% of those with a high school diploma or less (image1).

Moreover, there is a noticeable trend over time where the partisan divide on these issues has grown more pronounced. The gap between Republicans and Democrats in their views on U.S. global engagement has widened since 2013 (image3), and similarly, the difference in views on how the U.S. has handled the coronavirus outbreak has also increased (image6).

In conclusion, Republicans, especially conservative ones, tend to favor a more isolationist approach, believing the U.S. does too much in global engagement and should focus on domestic issues. In contrast, Democrats, particularly liberals, are more supportive of international assistance, reflecting a broader belief in the U.S.'s role in addressing global challenges. Higher education levels generally correlate with a stronger inclination towards supporting international aid, regardless of political affiliation.

Americans' confidence levels in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China show a significant gap compared to their views on the seriousness of various issues related to China. For instance, while a majority of Americans perceive cyberattacks from China and China's growing military power as very serious problems, they exhibit less faith in Biden to address these issues. According to image1, only 63% of Americans have confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China, indicating a notable disparity. This is further illustrated by image7, where 86% and 76% of Americans consider cyberattacks from China and China's growing military power to be very serious, respectively, yet only 32% and 41% have a lot of confidence in Biden to handle these issues.

Moreover, the data in image2 shows an increase in concern regarding the loss of U.S. jobs to China and China's growing military power. In 2021, 53% of Americans see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem, up from 47% in 2020, and 49% view China's growing military power as a very serious problem, largely unchanged from 2020. However, the corresponding figures for confidence in Biden to address these issues are lower, with only 59% and 66% having a lot of confidence, respectively.

Additionally, partisan differences play a significant role. As seen in image4, Democrats and those leaning Democratic are much more confident in Biden's ability to deal with China (83% for Democrats and 81% for liberal Democrats), whereas Republicans and those leaning Republican are far less confident (19% for Republicans and 30% for moderate or conservative Republicans). This is further emphasized in image11, showing that partisans are sharply divided over confidence in Biden to deal with China.

In conclusion, while Americans are increasingly concerned about issues like cyberattacks and China's growing military power, their confidence in Biden to address these problems remains relatively low, highlighting a disconnect between perception and trust.

According to the data, the level of confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China varies significantly across different demographic groups. For instance, women are more confident than men in Biden's ability to handle China, with 59% of women and 48% of men expressing confidence [10]. Additionally, Black and Hispanic adults exhibit higher levels of confidence compared to White adults, with 82% and 70% of Black and Hispanic adults, respectively, having confidence in Biden, whereas only 43% of White adults do so [10]. College-educated individuals are also more confident than those with less schooling, with 60% of those with a college degree expecting Biden to be effective in dealing with China, compared to 50% of those without a college degree [10].

The primary concerns Americans have regarding China are illustrated in the graphs. Among the issues, cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights are identified as the most serious problems, with over half of Americans describing them as very serious [12]. These concerns are further highlighted in the image showing the percentage of people who view each issue as very serious, where cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, and China's growing military power are at 100%, indicating high levels of concern [image1].

Moreover, the partisan divide is evident, with Democrats and leaners towards the Democratic Party expressing much higher confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China compared to Republicans and leaners towards the Republican Party. Specifically, 83% of Democrats and leaners have confidence in Biden on China, whereas only 19% of Republicans and leaners say the same. Even more strikingly, conservative Republicans have an even lower confidence level at just 10%, compared to 30% for moderate or liberal Republicans [7]. This is reflected in the image showing the significant difference in confidence levels between Republicans and Democrats, with a 19-point increase in the Republican side for dealing with China [image7].

In conclusion, the primary concerns Americans have regarding China include cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies, while the level of confidence in Biden to address these issues varies notably among different demographic groups, with women, minorities, and college-educated individuals showing greater confidence.

The confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly among different demographic and political groups. According to the data, Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents express much greater confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China, with 83% having confidence, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners [3][4]. This partisan divide is stark, reflecting deep-seated ideological differences.

The image `image1` illustrates the contrasting views on prioritizing economic relations versus respecting human rights. It shows that a significant portion of respondents believe the U.S. should prioritize economic relations even if it means not addressing human rights issues, indicating a potential tension between economic interests and moral considerations.

In terms of gender and race, women and non-white racial groups tend to be more confident in Biden's ability to handle China. Specifically, 59% of women and 82% of Black adults have confidence in Biden, compared to 43% of White adults [11]. This suggests that demographic factors play a role in shaping attitudes towards Biden's effectiveness in managing the U.S.-China relationship.

Age also influences confidence, with younger adults generally more confident than older adults. College-educated individuals are more likely to trust Biden on China than those without a college degree, with 60% of college graduates expressing confidence compared to 50% of those with less education [11].

Regarding specific concerns, the image `image7` highlights that the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights are considered the most serious issues. The loss of U.S. jobs to China saw a 6-point increase in perceived seriousness since 2020, reaching 53%, while China's growing military power and human rights policies were seen as very serious problems by 49% and 57% of respondents, respectively. Cyberattacks from China and tensions between China and Hong Kong also increased in perceived seriousness, with both seeing a 19-point increase from 2020 to 2021 [2][7].

In conclusion, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China is heavily influenced by political affiliation, with Democrats showing much greater trust. Demographic factors such as gender and race also play a role, with women and non-white racial groups tending to be more confident. The most serious concerns about China include the loss of U.S. jobs, military power, and human rights policies, reflecting broader economic and security anxieties.

According to the Pew Research Center data, confidence levels in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China vary significantly across different demographic groups. For instance, women are more confident than men in Biden's ability to handle China, with 59% of women having confidence compared to 48% of men [7]. Additionally, Black and Hispanic adults express more confidence in Biden on this issue than White adults, with 82% and 70% of Black and Hispanic adults, respectively, having confidence, compared to just 43% of White adults [7].

In terms of party affiliation, there are stark differences in confidence levels. Democrats and their leaners have a much higher level of confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, with 83% expressing confidence, compared to only 19% of Republicans and their leaners [11]. Furthermore, conservative Republicans express even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%), although conservative and moderate Democrats are about equally confident (86% and 81%, respectively) [11].

Regarding major concerns, the data indicates that Americans are particularly worried about cyber attacks from China, with roughly two-thirds considering them a very serious problem [2], and this concern has increased by 7 percentage points since 2020. Other significant concerns include the loss of U.S. jobs to China, with 53% seeing it as a very serious problem, and China's growing military power, with 49% considering it a very serious problem [6].

The data also highlights that partisan differences play a significant role in these concerns. For example, the share of Republicans who believe the loss of U.S. jobs to China poses a very serious problem has increased by 14 percentage points since 2020, whereas there was no significant change among Democrats [8]. Similarly, the concern over China's growing military power has remained relatively stable, but there is a notable difference in perception between Republicans and Democrats [6].

Lastly, the concern over China-related issues tends to be higher among older Americans, with those aged 65 and older being at least 20 points more likely than those aged 18 to 29 to consider most issues very serious problems [9].

![Confidence levels in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China](image7)
![Concerns about various China-related issues](image2)

In summary, while a majority of Americans are concerned about China-related issues, confidence in Biden's ability to address these challenges varies widely depending on factors such as gender, race, education, and political affiliation. The key concerns include cyber attacks, job losses, and military power, reflecting a complex mix of economic, security, and human rights issues.
